Key Arguments: The proposed legislation threatens freedom of speech in Australia.
The new powers for ACMA could lead to a slippery slope of increased censorship.
The legislation does not align with the International Covenant on Civil and Political Rights (ICCPR).
Fundamental rights should not be limited without clear and unambiguous language from the legislature.
Any changes to human rights laws should be exhaustively discussed and scrutinized, potentially requiring a referendum.
Notable Quotes: I wish to make known my objection to any move by the parliament of Australia to curtail the rights of citizens of Australia to Freedom of Speech.
This is merely starts us down what will inevitably become an increasingly slippery slope.
The end never justifies the means.

Any move by parliament to introduce changes to the Human Rights issues as Freedom of Speech under the context of the Covenant referred to herein, that have not been exhaustively discussed and scrutinised... ought not be introduced as law.
